title: Valtteri Bottas wins Japanese Grand Prix while Mercedes grab Constructors' Championship
text:

Valtteri Bottas withstood a Lewis Hamilton storm brewing behind him to claim a surprise victory at the Japanese Grand Prix.

After the threat of Typhoon Hagibis moved clear of Suzuka on Sunday morning, Bottas swept past his woeful Ferrari rivals to claim his first victory in 12 races.

Ferrari had looked in pole position to win after Sebastian Vettel topped the delayed qualifying session but the German had a woeful start off the line and Bottas reaped the rewards.

The win guarantees Mercedes a sixth consecutive constructors' world title but Hamilton, who came home in third behind Vettel, was left frustrated with his team's tactics.

(Image: REUTERS)

In fact, he was livid with the team when on lap 21 they put him on the medium tyres that were supposed to last the entirety of the race.

But they did not and the championship leader was ultimately forced to pit for an unscheduled second stop that ruined his chances of victory.

Team boss Toto Wolff told Hamilton seconds after crossing the line: “Lewis, this is Toto, difficult day today, but we've just won the constructors' championship for the sixth time in a row, thank you for the help and your support. Great driving.”

(Image: Getty Images)

The Brit now leads Bottas by 64 points with just 104 to play for in the remaining four races of the season and a sixth world championship could be wrapped up by the next round in Mexico.

A frosty Hamilton said after the race: "Firstly it's congratulations to the team to win it six times in a row. I really just wanted to get the best points for the team."

For Bottas, it was a morale-boosting victory after a dreadful run of form that has seen his team-mate spearhead all-conquering Mercedes' challenge for another remarkable title crown.

(Image: REUTERS)

The combination of Bottas and Hamilton’s finishes, plus Ferrari’s failure to improve on their second and sixth place with Vettel and Charles Leclerc, means a Mercedes driver is guaranteed to win the drivers’ title.

It breaks the record of five title doubles set by Michael Schumacher and Ferrari from 2000-2004 and confirms this dominant Mercedes team as the greatest in Formula One history.

Bottas said: "I'm happy, very happy. Obviously it was a close qualifying and starting third is not easy here but you don't give up and anything is possible.

"I had a really nice start and Sebastian had an issue so I got the lead and the pace was super good. I enjoyed it and had fun.”

(Image: REUTERS)

Indeed, Bottas seemingly had the win wrapped up at the first corner after Vettel’s alleged false start, for which he was found not guilty, and Leclerc’s slow start off the line.

Leclerc’s misery was compounded following an early collision with Red Bull’s Max Verstappen and although he came home sixth, he faces an investigation for that incident.

Another day to savour for Mercedes, another one to forget for Ferrari.
description: Bottas becomes just the third Mercedes driver to win the Japanese GP
